Here are some UX considerations for the above UI elements:

1. Search bar: The search bar should be prominently placed on the page and be easily accessible. The text input field should be large enough for the user to easily enter their keyword.
2. Search button: The search button should be placed close to the search bar and be easily noticeable. It should be labeled clearly, for example, "Search" or "Go".
3. Results list: The results list should be easy to read and navigate, with clear and concise image descriptions. The images should be arranged in a grid-like layout, with enough white space between each image to make it easy to distinguish between them.
4. Image thumbnail: The image thumbnail should be large enough to provide a clear preview of the full image. The aspect ratio of the thumbnail should be consistent across all images in the results list.
5. Image title: The image title should be concise and descriptive, using keywords that accurately describe the image. It should be placed below the image thumbnail, in a font that is easily readable.
6. View button: The view button should be placed below the image thumbnail and be easily noticeable. It should be labeled clearly, for example, "View" or "Open".
7. Save button: The save button should be placed below the image thumbnail and be easily noticeable. It should be labeled clearly, for example, "Save" or "Pin".
8. Share button: The share button should be placed below the image thumbnail and be easily noticeable. It should be labeled clearly, for example, "Share" or "Send".
9. Loading indicator: The loading indicator should be placed at the center of the page and be easily noticeable. It should be animated, for example, a spinning wheel or progress bar, to indicate that the search results are being loaded.
10. Error message: The error message should be displayed prominently, for example, at the center of the page, and be easily noticeable. It should be written in a clear and concise manner, for example, "No results found" or "Network error". The error message should be displayed for a sufficient amount of time, allowing the user to read it and take action, if necessary.
